Platform neutral API, abstract classes and operandsÂ¶

group asmjit_base

Contains all AsmJit classes and helper functions that are neutral or abstract. All abstract classes are reimplemented for every supported architecture.

Defines

ASMJIT_PROPAGATE_ERROR(_Exp_)

Typedefs

typedef int64_t SignedPtr

64-bit signed pointer, compatible with JIT and non-JIT generators.

typedef uint64_t Ptr

64-bit unsigned pointer, compatible with JIT and non-JIT generators.

typedef uint32_t Error

Enums

kCodeGen enum

CodeGen features.

Values:

  • kCodeGenOptimizedAlign = 0 -

    Emit optimized code-alignment sequences.

    X86/X64:

    Default align sequence used by X86/X64 architecture is one-byte 0x90 opcode that is mostly shown by disassemblers as nop. However there are more optimized align sequences for 2-11 bytes that may execute faster. If this feature is enabled asmjit will generate specialized sequences for alignment between 1 to 11 bytes. Also when x86x64::Compiler is used, it may add rex prefixes into the code to make some instructions larger so no alignment sequences are needed.

    true.

  • kCodeGenPredictedJumps = 1 -

    Emit jump-prediction hints.

    X86/X64:

    Jump prediction is usually based on the direction of the jump. If the jump is backward it is usually predicted as taken; and if the jump is forward it is usually predicted as not-taken. The reason is that loops generally use backward jumps and conditions usually use forward jumps. However this behavior can be overridden by using instruction prefixes. If this option is enabled these hints will be emitted.

    true.

kCpuVendor enum

Cpu vendor IDs.

Cpu vendor IDs are specific for AsmJit library. Vendor ID is not directly read from cpuid result, instead it’s based on CPU vendor string.

Values:

  • kCpuVendorUnknown = 0 -

    Unknown CPU vendor.

  • kCpuVendorIntel = 1 -

    Intel CPU vendor.

  • kCpuVendorAmd = 2 -

    AMD CPU vendor.

  • kCpuVendorNSM = 3 -

    National Semiconductor CPU vendor (applies also to Cyrix processors).

  • kCpuVendorTransmeta = 4 -

    Transmeta CPU vendor.

  • kCpuVendorVia = 5 -

    VIA CPU vendor.

kOperandType enum

Operand types that can be encoded in Operand.

Values:

  • kOperandTypeNone = 0 -

    Invalid operand, used only internally (not initialized Operand).

  • kOperandTypeReg = 1 -

    Operand is a register.

  • kOperandTypeVar = 2 -

    Operand is a variable.

  • kOperandTypeMem = 3 -

    Operand is a memory.

  • kOperandTypeImm = 4 -

    Operand is an immediate value.

  • kOperandTypeLabel = 5 -

    Operand is a label.

kOperandId enum

Operand id masks used to determine the operand type.

Values:

  • kOperandIdVar = 0x80000000U -

    Operand id refers to BaseVar.

  • kOperandIdNum = 0x7FFFFFFFU -

    Operand id to real index mask.

kRegClass enum

Register class.

Values:

  • kRegClassGp = 0 -

    Gp register class (any architecture).

  • kRegClassInvalid = 0xFF -

    Invalid register class.

kInstCode enum

Instruction codes (stub).

Values:

  • kInstNone = 0 -

    No instruction.

kInstOptions enum

Instruction options (stub).

Values:

  • kInstOptionNone = 0x00 -

    No instruction options.

  • kInstOptionShortForm = 0x01 -

    Emit short form of the instruction.

    X86/X64:

    Short form is mostly related to jmp and jcc instructions, but can be used by other instructions supporting 8-bit or 32-bit immediates. This option can be dangerous if the short jmp/jcc is required, but not encodable due to large displacement, in such case an error happens and the whole assembler/compiler stream is unusable.

  • kInstOptionLongForm = 0x02 -

    Emit long form of the instruction.

    X86/X64:

    Long form is mosrlt related to jmp and jcc instructions, but like the kInstOptionShortForm option it can be used by other instructions supporting both 8-bit and 32-bit immediates.

  • kInstOptionTaken = 0x04 -

    Condition is likely to be taken (instruction).

  • kInstOptionNotTaken = 0x08 -

    Condition is unlikely to be taken (instruction).

kSize enum

Common size of registers and pointers.

Values:

  • kSizeByte = 1 -

    1 byte size.

  • kSizeWord = 2 -

    2 bytes size.

  • kSizeDWord = 4 -

    4 bytes size.

  • kSizeQWord = 8 -

    8 bytes size.

  • kSizeTWord = 10 -

    10 bytes size.

  • kSizeOWord = 16 -

    16 bytes size.

  • kSizeYWord = 32 -

    32 bytes size.

kMemType enum

Type of memory operand.

Values:

  • kMemTypeBaseIndex = 0 -

    Memory operand is a combination of base register, optional index register and optional displacement.

    Note

    The Assembler interprets kMemTypeBaseIndex and kMemTypeStackIndex types the same way, but Compiler interprets kMemTypeBaseIndex as [base + index] and kMemTypeStackIndex as [stack(base) + index].

  • kMemTypeStackIndex = 1 -

    Memory operand is a combination of variable’s memory location, optional index register and displacement.

    Note

    The Assembler interprets kMemTypeBaseIndex and kMemTypeStackIndex types in the same way, but Compiler interprets kMemTypeBaseIndex as [base + index] and kMemTypeStackIndex as [stack(base) + index].

  • kMemTypeLabel = 2 -

    Memory operand refers to the memory location specified by a label.

  • kMemTypeAbsolute = 3 -

    Memory operand is an absolute memory location.

    Supported mostly by x86, truncated to a 32-bit value when running in 64-bit mode (x64).

kVarType enum

Values:

  • kVarTypeInt8 = 0 -

    Variable is signed 8-bit integer.

  • kVarTypeUInt8 = 1 -

    Variable is unsigned 8-bit integer.

  • kVarTypeInt16 = 2 -

    Variable is signed 16-bit integer.

  • kVarTypeUInt16 = 3 -

    Variable is unsigned 16-bit integer.

  • kVarTypeInt32 = 4 -

    Variable is signed 32-bit integer.

  • kVarTypeUInt32 = 5 -

    Variable is unsigned 32-bit integer.

  • kVarTypeInt64 = 6 -

    Variable is signed 64-bit integer.

  • kVarTypeUInt64 = 7 -

    Variable is unsigned 64-bit integer.

  • kVarTypeIntPtr = 8 -

    Variable is target intptr_t (not compatible with host intptr_t).

  • kVarTypeUIntPtr = 9 -

    Variable is target uintptr_t (not compatible with host uintptr_t).

  • kVarTypeFp32 = 10 -

    Variable is 32-bit floating point (single precision).

  • kVarTypeFp64 = 11 -

    Variable is 64-bit floating point (double precision).

  • kVarTypeInvalid = 0xFF -

    Invalid variable type.

  • _kVarTypeIntStart = kVarTypeInt8 -
  • _kVarTypeIntEnd = kVarTypeUIntPtr -
  • _kVarTypeFpStart = kVarTypeFp32 -
  • _kVarTypeFpEnd = kVarTypeFp64 -

kRelocMode enum

Values:

  • kRelocAbsToAbs = 0 -
  • kRelocRelToAbs = 1 -
  • kRelocAbsToRel = 2 -
  • kRelocTrampoline = 3 -

kError enum

AsmJit error codes.

Values:

  • kErrorOk = 0 -

    No error (success).

    This is default state and state you want.

  • kErrorNoHeapMemory = 1 -

    Heap memory allocation failed.

  • kErrorNoVirtualMemory = 2 -

    Virtual memory allocation failed.

  • kErrorInvalidArgument = 3 -

    Invalid argument.

  • kErrorInvalidState = 4 -

    Invalid state.

  • kErrorAssemblerUnknownInst = 5 -

    Unknown instruction. This happens only if instruction code is out of bounds. Shouldn’t happen.

  • kErrorAssemblerIllegalInst = 6 -

    Illegal instruction, usually generated by asmjit::Assembler class when emitting instruction opcode. If this error is generated the target buffer is not affected by this invalid instruction.

    You can also get this status code if you are under x64 (64-bit x86) and you tried to decode instruction using AH, BH, CH or DH register with REX prefix. These registers can’t be accessed if REX prefix is used and AsmJit didn’t check for this situation in intrinsics (Compiler takes care of this and rearrange registers if needed).

    Examples that will raise kErrorAssemblerIllegalInst error (a is Assembler instance):

     a.mov(dword_ptr(eax), al); // Invalid address size.
 a.mov(byte_ptr(r10), ah);  // Undecodable instruction (AH used with r10
                            // that can be encoded by using REX prefix only)

    Note

    In debug mode you get assertion failure instead of setting error code.

  • kErrorAssemblerIllegalAddr = 7 -

    Illegal addressing used (unencodable).

  • kErrorAssemblerIllegalShortJump = 8 -

    Short jump instruction used, but displacement is out of bounds.

  • kErrorCompilerNoFunc = 9 -

    No function defined.

  • kErrorCompilerIncompleteFunc = 10 -

    Function generation is not finished by using Compiler::endFunc() or something bad happened during generation related to function. This can be missing compiler node, etc...

  • kErrorCompilerOverlappedArgs = 11 -

    Tried to generate a function with overlapped arguments.

  • kErrorCompilerNoRegs = 12 -

    Compiler can’t allocate registers.

  • kErrorCompilerOverlappedRegs = 13 -

    Compiler can’t allocate registers, because they overlap.

  • kErrorCompilerIncompatibleArg = 14 -

    Tried to call function with an incompatible argument.

  • kErrorCompilerIncompatibleRet = 15 -

    Incompatible return value.

  • kErrorCount = 16 -

    Count of AsmJit status codes. Can grow in future.

kGlobals enum

Values:

  • kInvalidValue = 0xFFFFFFFF -

    Invalid value or operand id.

  • kInvalidReg = 0xFF -

    Invalid register index.

  • kBufferGrow = 32U -

    Minimum reserved bytes in Buffer.

  • kMemAllocMinimum = 4096 -

    Minimum size of assembler/compiler code buffer.

  • kMemAllocGrowMax = 8192 * 1024 -

    Memory grow threshold.

    After the grow threshold is reached the capacity won’t be doubled anymore.

  • kMemAllocOverhead = sizeof(intptr_t) * 4 -

    Host memory allocator overhead.

    We decrement the overhead from our pools so the host operating system doesn’t need allocate an extra virtual page to put the data it needs to manage the requested memory block (for example if a single virtual page is 4096 and we require the same memory size we decrease our requirement by kMemAllocOverhead).

kArch enum

Architecture.

Values:

  • kArchNone = 0 -

    No/Unknown architecture.

  • kArchX86 = 1 -

    X86 architecture.

  • kArchX64 = 2 -

    X64 architecture, also called AMD64.

  • kArchArm = 4 -

    Arm architecture.

kStringOp enum

String operation.

Values:

  • kStringOpSet = 0 -

    Replace the current string by a given content.

  • kStringOpAppend = 1 -

    Append a given content to the current string.

kStringFormat enum

String format flags.

Values:

  • kStringFormatShowSign = 0x00000001 -
  • kStringFormatShowSpace = 0x00000002 -
  • kStringFormatAlternate = 0x00000004 -
  • kStringFormatSigned = 0x80000000 -

void assertionFailed(const char * exp, const char * file, int line)

Called in debug build on assertion failure.

If you have problems with assertions put a breakpoint at assertionFailed() function (asmjit/base/assert.cpp) to see what happened.

Parameters
  • exp -

    Expression that failed.

  • file -

    Source file name where it happened.

  • line -

    Line in the source file.

Label data.

Public Members

intptr_t offset

Label offset.

LabelLink * links

Label links chain.

class RelocData

Code relocation data (relative vs absolute addresses).

X86/X64:

X86 architecture uses 32-bit absolute addressing model by memory operands, but 64-bit mode uses relative addressing model (RIP + displacement). In code we are always using relative addressing model for referencing labels and embedded data. In 32-bit mode we must patch all references to absolute address before we can call generated function.

Public Members

uint32_t type

Type of relocation.

uint32_t size

Size of relocation (4 or 8 bytes).

Ptr from

Offset from code begin address.

Ptr data

Relative displacement from code begin address (not to offset) or absolute address.

class BaseAssembler

Base assembler.

This class implements core setialization API only. The platform specific methods and intrinsics is implemented by derived classes.

See
BaseCompiler.

Public Functions

Clear everything, but not deallocate buffers.

Reset everything (means also to free all buffers).

Called by clear() and reset() to clear all data related to derived class implementation.

size_t getOffset()

Get the current offset in the buffer (_cursor - _buffer).

size_t setOffset(size_t offset)

Set the current offset in the buffer to offset and get the previous offset value.

ASMJIT_API Error _grow(size_t n)

Grow the internal buffer.

The internal buffer will grow at least by n bytes so n bytes can be added to it. If n is zero or getOffset() + n is not greater than the current capacity of the buffer this function won’t do anything.

ASMJIT_API Error _reserve(size_t n)

Reserve the internal buffer to at least n bytes.

size_t getCodeSize()

Get current offset in buffer (same as getOffset() + getTramplineSize()).

size_t getTrampolineSize()

Get size of all possible trampolines needed to successfuly generate relative jumps to absolute addresses. This value is only non-zero if jmp of call instructions were used with immediate operand (this means jumping or calling an absolute address directly).

size_t getLabelsCount()

Get count of labels created.

Note
Label can be bound only once!

ASMJIT_API Error embed(const void * data, uint32_t size)

Embed data into the code buffer.

Error align(uint32_t m)

Align target buffer to m bytes.

Typical usage of this is to align labels at start of the inner loops.

Inserts nop() instructions or CPU optimized NOPs.

Error _align(uint32_t m)

Align target buffer to m bytes (virtual).

size_t relocCode(void * dst)

Simplifed version of relocCode() method designed for JIT.

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

size_t relocCode(void * dst, Ptr base)

Relocate code to a given address dst.

A given buffer will be overwritten, to get number of bytes required use getCodeSize().

Parameters
  • dst -

    Where the relocated code should me stored. The pointer can be address returned by virtual memory allocator or your own address if you want only to store the code for later reuse (or load, etc...).

  • addressBase -

    Base address used for relocation. When using JIT code generation, this will be the same as dst, only casted to system integer type. But when generating code for remote process then the value can be different.

Return Value
  • The -

    bytes used. Code-generator can create trampolines which are used when calling other functions inside the JIT code. However, these trampolines can be unused so the relocCode() returns the exact size needed for the function.

size_t _relocCode(void * dst, Ptr base)

Reloc code (virtual).

ASMJIT_API void * make()

Make is a convenience method to make and relocate the current code into the associated runtime.

What is needed is only to cast the returned pointer to your function type and then use it. If there was an error during make() NULL is returned and the last error code can be obtained by calling getError().

Public Members

uint8_t * _buffer

Buffer where the code is emitted (either live or temporary).

This is actually the base pointer of the buffer, to get the current position (cursor) look at the _cursor member.

uint8_t * _end

The end of the buffer (points to the first invalid byte).

The end of the buffer is calculated as _buffer + size.

uint8_t * _cursor

The current position in code _buffer.

uint32_t _trampolineSize

Size of possible trampolines.

const char * _comment

Inline comment that will be logged by the next instruction and set to NULL.

LabelLink * _unusedLinks

Linked list of unused links (LabelLink* structures)

PodVector < LabelData > _labels

Labels data.

PodVector < RelocData > _relocData

Relocations data.

class Operand

Operand can contain register, memory location, immediate, or label.

union asmjit::Operand::@16 @17

class BaseOp

Public Members

uint8_t op

Type of operand, see kOperandType.

uint8_t size

Size of operand (register, address, immediate, or variable).

uint8_t reserved0

Flags, each operand uses this byte for something else.

uint8_t reserved1

Reserved (not used).

uint32_t id

Operand id (private variable for BaseAssembler and BaseCompiler classes).

Note
Uninitialized operand has always set id to kInvalidValue.

class Imm

Immediate operand.

Immediate operand is usually part of instruction itself (it’s inlined after or before instruction opcode). Immediates can be only signed or unsigned integers.

To create immediate operand, use imm() and imm_u() constructors or constructors provided by Immediate class itself.

class Label

Label (jump target or data location).

Label represents locations typically used as jump targets, but may be also used as position where are stored constants or static variables. If you want to use Label you need first to associate it with BaseAssembler or BaseCompiler instance. To create new label use BaseAssembler::newLabel() or BaseCompiler::newLabel().

Example of using labels:

 // Create Assembler/Compiler.
 Assembler a;

 // Create Label instance.
 Label L_1(a);

 // ... your code ...

 // Using label, see @ref asmjit::BaseAssembler or @ref asmjit::BaseCompiler.
 a.jump(L_1);

 // ... your code ...

 // Bind label to current position, see @ref asmjit::BaseAssembler::bind()
 // or @ref asmjit::BaseCompiler::bind().
 a.bind(L_1);

Public Functions

Label()

Create new, unassociated label.

Label(uint32_t id)

Label(BaseAssembler & a)

Create new initialized label.

Label(BaseCompiler & c)

Create new initialized label.

Label(const Label & other)

Create reference to another label.

Label(const _NoInit &)

Label & operator=(const Label & other)

bool operator==(const Label & other)

bool operator!=(const Label & other)

class ErrorHandler

Public Functions

ASMJIT_API ErrorHandler()

Create a new ErrorHandler.

ASMJIT_API ~ErrorHandler()

Destroy the ErrorHandler.

ASMJIT_API ErrorHandler * addRef()

Reference this error handler.

Note
This member function is provided for convenience. The default implementation does nothing. If you are working in environment where multiple ErrorHandler instances are used in different Assembler and Compiler instances (or in multithreaded environment) you might want to provide your own functionality for reference counting. In that case override addRef() and release() functions to inc/dec your reference count value.

ASMJIT_API void release()

Release this error handler.

Note
This member function is provided for convenience. See addRef() for more detailed information related to reference counting.

bool handleError(Error code, const char * message)

Error handler (pure).

Error handler is called when an error happened. An error can happen in many places, but error handler is mostly used by Assembler and Compiler classes to report anything that may prevent correct code generation. There are multiple ways how the error handler can be used and each has it’s pros/cons.

AsmJit library doesn’t use exceptions and can be compiled with or without exception feature support. Even if the AsmJit library is compiled without exceptions it is exception-safe and handleError() can report an incoming error by throwing an exception of any type. It’s guaranteed that the exception won’t be catched by AsmJit and will be propagated to the code calling AsmJit Assembler or Compiler. Alternative to throwing exception is using setjmp() / longjmp() pair from the standard C library.

If the exception or setjmp() / longjmp() mechanism is used, the state of the Assember or Compiler is unchanged and if it’s possible the execution (instruction serialization) can continue. However if the error happened during any phase that translates or modifies the stored code (for example relocation done by Assembler or analysis/translation done by Compiler) the execution can’t continue and the error will be also stored in Assembler or Compiler.

Finally, if exceptions nor setjmp() / longjmp() mechanisms were used, you can still implement a compatible design by returning from your error handler. Returning true means that error was reported and AsmJit should continue execution. When false is returned, AsmJit sets the error immediately to the Assembler or Compiler and execution shouldn’t continue (this is the default behavior in case no error handler is used).

Public Static Functions

ASMJIT_API const char * asString(Error code)

Get printable version of AsmJit kError code.

class StringBuilder

String builder.

String builder was designed to be able to build a string using append like operation to append numbers, other strings, or signle characters. It can allocate it’s own buffer or use a buffer created on the stack.

String builder contains method specific to AsmJit functionality, used for logging or HTML output.

class VMem

Class that helps with allocating memory for executing code generated by JIT compiler.

There are defined functions that provides facility to allocate and free memory where can be executed code. If processor and operating system supports execution protection then you can’t run code from normally malloc()’ed memory.

Functions are internally implemented by operating system dependent way. VirtualAlloc() function is used for Windows operating system and mmap() for posix ones. If you want to study or create your own functions, look at VirtualAlloc() or mmap() documentation (depends on you target OS).

Under posix operating systems is also useable mprotect() function, that can enable execution protection to malloc()’ed memory block.

Public Static Functions

ASMJIT_API void * alloc(size_t length, size_t * allocated, bool canExecute)

Allocate virtual memory.

Pages are readable/writeable, but they are not guaranteed to be executable unless ‘canExecute’ is true. Returns the address of allocated memory, or NULL on failure.

ASMJIT_API void release(void * addr, size_t length)

Free memory allocated by alloc()

ASMJIT_API size_t getAlignment()

Get the alignment guaranteed by alloc().

ASMJIT_API size_t getPageSize()

Get size of the single page.

class Zone

Fast incremental memory allocator.

Memory allocator designed to allocate small objects that will be invalidated (free) all at once.

Public Functions

ASMJIT_API Zone(size_t chunkSize)

Create a new instance of Zone allocator.

Parameters
  • chunkSize -

    Default size of the first chunk.

ASMJIT_API ~Zone()

Destroy Zone instance.

ASMJIT_API void clear()

Free all allocated memory except first block that remains for reuse.

Note that this method will invalidate all instances using this memory allocated by this zone instance.

ASMJIT_API void reset()

Free all allocated memory at once.

Note that this method will invalidate all instances using this memory allocated by this zone instance.

size_t getChunkSize()

Get (default) chunk size.

void * alloc(size_t size)

Allocate size bytes of memory.

Pointer allocated by this way will be valid until Zone object is destroyed. To create class by this way use placement new and delete operators:

 // Example of simple class allocation.
 using namespace asmjit

 // Your class.
 class Object
 {
   // members...
 };

 // Your function
 void f()
 {
   // Create zone object with chunk size of 65536 bytes.
   Zone zone(65536);

   // Create your objects using zone object allocating, for example:
   Object* obj = new(zone.alloc(sizeof(YourClass))) Object();

   // ... lifetime of your objects ...

   // Destroy your objects:
   obj->~Object();

   // Zone destructor will free all memory allocated through it, you can
   // call @c zone.reset() if you wan't to reuse current @ref Zone.
 }

template < typename T >
T * allocT(size_t size = sizeof(T))

Like alloc(), but returns T*.

ASMJIT_API void * _alloc(size_t size)

void * calloc(size_t size)

Allocate size bytes of zeroed memory.

ASMJIT_API void * _calloc(size_t size)

ASMJIT_API void * dup(const void * data, size_t size)

Helper to duplicate data.

ASMJIT_API char * sdup(const char * str)

Helper to duplicate string.

ASMJIT_API char * sformat(const char * str, ...)

Helper to duplicate formatted string, maximum length is 256 bytes.

Public Members

Chunk * _chunks

Last allocated chunk of memory.

Default chunk size.
